case_name: Income-tax Department v. Hindu undivided family of the Raja of Bhor

facts.text: The respondent is a Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: the respondent, a Hindu undivided family, is entitled to exemption from taxation in respect of the interest income from Government securities held by it, under a numberification of the Government of India dated March 21, 1922

facts.text: The late Raja of Bhor held certain Government securities

anchor.surface_text: The late Raja of Bhor held certain Government securities and up to the assessment year 1953-54, he was assessed in the status of individual in respect of his income.

facts.text: Up to the assessment year 1953-54, the late Raja of Bhor was assessed in the status of individual in respect of his income

anchor.surface_text: and up to the assessment year 1953-54, he was assessed in the status of individual in respect of his income. He died on October 9, 1954. His estate including the Government securities thereupon passed to his three sons who companystituted a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The late Raja of Bhor died on October 9, 1954

anchor.surface_text: He died on October 9, 1954. His estate including the Government securities thereupon passed to his three sons who companystituted a Hindu undivided family. The eldest of them succeeded to the title of Raja of Bhor.

facts.text: His estate including the Government securities passed to his three sons who constituted a Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: His estate including the Government securities thereupon passed to his three sons who companystituted a Hindu undivided family. The eldest of them succeeded to the title of Raja of Bhor. For the assessment years 1954-55 to 1958-59 the present Raja of Bhor filed returns as a Hindu undivided family companysisting of himself and of his two brothers.

facts.text: The eldest son succeeded to the title of Raja of Bhor

anchor.surface_text: The eldest of them succeeded to the title of Raja of Bhor. For the assessment years 1954-55 to 1958-59 the present Raja of Bhor filed returns as a Hindu undivided family companysisting of himself and of his two brothers.

facts.text: For assessment years 1954-55 to 1958-59, the present Raja of Bhor filed returns as a Hindu undivided family consisting of himself and his two brothers

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1954-55 to 1958-59 the present Raja of Bhor filed returns as a Hindu undivided family companysisting of himself and of his two brothers. He claimed exemption in respect of the interest income with regard to the Government securities on the ground that it was exempt under the numberification issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: The Raja claimed exemption in respect of the interest income from Government securities under notification issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: He claimed exemption in respect of the interest income with regard to the Government securities on the ground that it was exempt under the numberification issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 60 empowers the Central Government, by numberification in the Official Gazette, to make exemption, reduction in the rate or other modifications in respect of the income-tax in favour of any class of persons.

facts.text: Central Government issued a notification on March 21, 1922 under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of its powers under section 60, the Central Government issued a numberification on March 21, 1922, which was to the following effect The following classes of income shall be exempt from the tax payable under the said Act

facts.text: Notification exempts interest on Government securities held by, or on behalf of, Ruling Chiefs and Princes of India as their private property

anchor.surface_text: the interest on Government securities held by, or on behalf of, Ruling Chiefs and Princes of India as their private property. The Income-tax Officer rejected the claim of the assessee on the ground that the securities were the properties of the Hindu undivided family of whom the present ruler and his brothers are members and they cannot lay claim to these securities as their private properties as they belong to the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the claim of the assessee that securities were properties of the Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the claim of the assessee on the ground that the securities were the properties of the Hindu undivided family of whom the present ruler and his brothers are members and they cannot lay claim to these securities as their private properties as they belong to the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who took the view that the Hindu undivided family was holding securities on behalf of the Ruling Chief or Princes of Indian States, and as such the exemption companytained in the numberification was application.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed the appeal of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter he allowed the appeal of the assessee. The income-tax department took the matter in appeal to the Appellate. Tribunal which affirmed the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax department appealed to the Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax department took the matter in appeal to the Appellate. Tribunal which affirmed the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal affirmed the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: Tribunal which affirmed the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and dismissed the appeal. At the instance of the income-tax department the Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court on the following question of law

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court at the instance of the income-tax department

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the income-tax department the Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court on the following question of law Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the interest on securities assessable under section 8 of the Income-tax Act was exempt from tax in the assessees hands in view of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21, 1922, issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: High Court of Bombay answered the question in the affirmative in favour of the assessee by judgment dated October 19, 1962

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated October 19, 1962, the High Court of Bombay answered the question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. These appeals are brought in pursuance of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under section 66A 2  of the Income- tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: These appeals are brought pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under section 66A(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are brought in pursuance of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under section 66A 2  of the Income- tax Act, 1922. It was argued by Mr. Mitra, in the first place, that the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers were number Ruling Chiefs or Princes within the meaning of the numberification of the Central Government dated March 21, 1922

facts.text: Appellant conceded before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the notification

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, number possible for us to entertain this argument, because the appellant had companyceded before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the numberification referred to above

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal order dated February 9, 1961 expressly recorded the concession of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: , and it is therefore number open number to the appellant to companytend that the securities were number held for or on behalf of the Ruling Chief and Princes of India within the meaning of the numberification. The companycession made by the appellant is expressly numbered by the Appellate Tribunal in its order dated February 9, 1961

facts.text: Agreed statement of the case dated July 28, 1961 submitted to High Court under section 66(1) referred to the concession

anchor.surface_text: and reference has also been made to the companycession of the appellant in the agreed statement of the case dated July 28, 1961, submitted to the High Court under section 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The present Raja of Bhor and his two brothers constituted a Mitakshara coparcenary

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers companystituted a Mitakshara companyarcenary and it is well-established that the essence of a companyarcenary under the Mitakshara law is unity of ownership.

facts.text: The property is held by the assessee on behalf of the present Raja of Bhor and his two brothers

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore manifest, in the present case, that the property is held by the assessee on behalf of the present Raja of Bhor and his two brothers and the assessee is therefore entitled to exemption from income-tax on the income from the securities.

facts.text: The assessee is entitled to exemption from income-tax on the income from the securities

anchor.surface_text: and the assessee is therefore entitled to exemption from income-tax on the income from the securities.

issues.text: whether the respondent, a Hindu undivided family, is entitled to exemption from taxation in respect of the interest income from Government securities held by it, under a notification of the Government of India dated March 21, 1922, issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration in these appeals is whether the respondent, a Hindu undivided family, is entitled to exemption from taxation in respect of the interest income from Government securities held by it, under a notification of the Government of India dated March 21, 1922,

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the interest on securities assessable under section 8 of the Income-tax Act was exempt from tax in the assessees hands in view of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21, 1922, issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the interest on securities assessable under section 8 of the Income-tax Act was exempt from tax in the assessees hands in view of the Notification No. 878F dated March 21, 1922, issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act ?

issues.text: whether the appellant is estopped by its concession before the Appellate Tribunal from contending that the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers were not Ruling Chiefs or Princes within the meaning of the notification and that the question arises out of the Tribunal's order

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, not possible for us to entertain this argument, because the appellant had conceded before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the notification referred to above

issues.text: whether the Hindu undivided family holds the Government securities as a separate legal entity distinct from its coparcener members under Hindu law such that the exemption under the notification does not apply to income assessed in the hands of the HUF

anchor.surface_text: It was then contended by Mr. Mitra on behalf of the appellant that the securities belonged to the Hindu undivided family which was a separate unit of assessment in contradistinction to its members. It was therefore argued by Mr. Mitra that since the securities belonged to the Hindu undivided family, the exemption contained in the notification dated March 21, 1922, will not apply to the present case.

arguments.claim: The Raja of Bhor and his two brothers were not Ruling Chiefs or Princes within the meaning of the notification of the Central Government dated March 21, 1922

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Mitra, in the first place, that the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers were not Ruling Chiefs or Princes within the meaning of the notification of the Central Government dated March 21, 1922, and the High Court was therefore justified in holding that the assessee was entitled to claim exemption under clause 3 of the notification.

anchor.surface_text: It was then contended by Mr. Mitra on behalf of the appellant that the securities belonged to the Hindu undivided family which was a separate unit of assessment in contradistinction to its members. It was therefore argued by Mr. Mitra that since the securities belonged to the Hindu undivided family, the exemption contained in the notification dated March 21, 1922, will not apply to the present case.

arguments.court_reasoning: HUF lacks separate legal personality under Hindu law; Mitakshara coparcenary involves unity of ownership; property held on behalf of coparceners who qualify as Ruling Chiefs/Princes

anchor.surface_text: He claimed exemption in respect of the interest income with regard to the Government securities on the ground that it was exempt under the notification issued under section 60 of the Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 60 empowers the Central Government, by notification in the Official Gazette, to make exemption, reduction in the rate or other modifications in respect of the income-tax in favour of any class of persons.

arguments.court_reasoning: HUF holds securities on behalf of qualifying coparceners (Ruling Chief and Princes)

arguments.claim: The securities were the properties of the Hindu undivided family and cannot be claimed as private properties of the present ruler and his brothers

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecurities were the properties of the Hindu undivided family of whom the present ruler and his brothers are members and they cannot lay claim to these

arguments.court_reasoning: Overruled by AAC, Tribunal, High Court, and Supreme Court on basis of 'on behalf of' language and Hindu law

arguments.claim: The Hindu undivided family was holding securities on behalf of the Ruling Chief or Princes of Indian States, so the exemption contained in the notification was applicable

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who took the view that the Hindu undivided family was holding securities on behalf of the Ruling Chief or Princes of Indian States, and as such the exemption contained in the notification was applicable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: m to these securities as their private properties as they belong to the Hindu undivided family. The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assi

arguments.court_reasoning: Affirmed by Tribunal, High Court, and Supreme Court

arguments.claim: In a Mitakshara coparcenary, there is unity of ownership in the whole body of coparceners; property held by HUF is on behalf of coparceners; assessee entitled to exemption as securities held on behalf of Ruling Chief and Princes

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers constituted a Mitakshara coparcenary and it is well-established that the essence of a coparcenary under the Mitakshara law is unity of ownership. The ownership of the coparcenary property is in the whole body of coparceners.

arguments.claim: The question regarding interpretation of notification as to whether parties are Ruling Chiefs/Princes does not arise out of the Tribunal order due to appellant's concession

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, not possible for us to entertain this argument, because the appellant had conceded before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the notification referred to above, and it is therefore not open to the appellant to contend that the securities were not held for or on behalf of the Ruling Chief and Princes of India within the meaning of the notification.

holdings.text: The appellant is bound by its concession before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the notification, and it is therefore not open to the appellant to contend that the securities were not held for or on behalf of the Ruling Chief and Princes of India within the meaning of the notification; the question does not arise out of the order of the Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, number possible for us to entertain this argument, because the appellant had companyceded before the Appellate Tribunal that the present Raja of Bhor was a Ruling Chief and his two brothers were princes within the meaning of the numberification referred to above

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession expressly recorded in Tribunal order dated February 9, 1961 and agreed statement of case dated July 28, 1961; no such question raised or argued before Tribunal.

holdings.text: Merely because the Hindu undivided family is treated as a separate unit of assessment for income-tax purposes under the Income-tax Act, 1922, it does not follow that under Hindu law the property of the Hindu undivided family belongs to it as a corporate unit with a separate legal personality distinct from the individual members composing it.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that for the purposes of income-tax the Hindu undivided family is assessed as a distinct entity or unit of assessment under the provisions of the Income-tax Act, 1922 in respect of the joint estate of the members the Hindu undivided family in taxed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proprietary rights determined by Hindu law, not income-tax assessment status; HUF lacks corporate personality under Hindu law.

holdings.text: In a Mitakshara coparcenary, the essence is unity of ownership in the whole body of coparceners with community of interest and unity of possession; each coparcener has rights over the entirety of coparcenary property till partition under the doctrine of samudavika swatwa or aggregate ownership.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Raja of Bhor and his two brothers companystituted a Mitakshara companyarcenary and it is well-established that the essence of a companyarcenary under the Mitakshara law is unity of ownership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established by precedents including Judicial Committee in Katama Natchiar v. Rajah of Shivagunga and Lord Westbury in Appovier v. Rama Subba Aiyan; birth-right theory leads to aggregate ownership.

holdings.text: The property (Government securities) is held by the assessee (Hindu undivided family) on behalf of the present Raja of Bhor and his two brothers (Ruling Chief and Princes), and the assessee is therefore entitled to exemption from income-tax on the income from the securities under the notification dated March 21, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore manifest, in the present case, that the property is held by the assessee on behalf of the present Raja of Bhor and his two brothers and the assessee is therefore entitled to exemption from income-tax on the income from the securities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification exempts interest on securities held by or on behalf of Ruling Chiefs and Princes as private property; applied via Mitakshara coparcenary unity of ownership where coparceners qualify.

Rajah of Shivagunga There is companymunity of interest and unity of possession between all the members of the family, and upon the death of any one of them the other may well take by survivorship that in which they had during the deceaseds lifetime a companymon interest and a companymon possession.

anchor.surface_text: Appovier v. Rama Subba Aiyan . His interest in the companyarcenary property is a fluctuating interest which is capable being enlarged by death in the family and liable to be diminished by birth in the family.
